update.description:
This PR is based on the earlier contribution from [PR #78](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/78/issue-23-coordinate-the-physics-and/diff) that began to address [Issue #23](#!/osrf/vrx/issues/23/coordinate-the-physics-and-visualization) for synchronizing the visual and physical wave fields.  Based on that initial work I’ve connected the method with our WAM-V dynamics and general purpose buoyancy plugins.  

This also implements an additional method for generating the component waves based on a standard family of oceanographic wave spectra.  

Added documentation: 

* [Wavefield Implementation](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/documentation/wavefield_generation): How the model is implemented to keep the visual and physical models in sync.
* [Wavefield Envelope](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/documentation/wavefield_envelope): Describes the ranges of wavefield parameters for VRX with examples of different seastates and how we measure consistency of the visual and physical models.
update.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

pull_request.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

pullrequest.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

content.raw:
TLDR: The testing below suggests that if we could simplify the implementation, synchronizing the visual and physical wavefield would add functionality for higher seastates without too much computational or complexity costs.

Based on team discussion, attempting to quantify the tradeoffs involved in this PR

**Pros:**

* Additional visual fidelity associated with synchronizing visual and physical ocean model.
* Additional sensor simulation fidelity for simulation of cameras and lidar.

**Cons:**

* Additional code complexity. Current implementation is quite complex. Considering a refactoring to simplify implementation and remove the capability to change wave parameters during simulation
* Added computational requirements

**Computational Requirements**

Below are results taken from `top` to quantify the relative resource usage of the simulation before and after this PR. Note that the proposed modification to simplify the implementation may reduce the computational load. Both implementations ran at RTF ~ 1.0.

| Implementation | gzserver %CPU | gzserver RES / SHR | gzclient %CPU | gzclient RES/SHR |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Not synch’ed \(original\) | 101 | 441,704 / 144,832 | 30 | 370,260 / 138,180 |
| Sync’ed, full implementation before refactor | 117 | 441,484 / 141,436 | 31 | 332,272 / 133,396 |
| Sync’ed, refactored implementation. | 118 | 411,556 / 141,368 | 25 | 328,396 / 133,364 |

So, a slight uptick in resource usage. I suspect that this is due to the fact that more objects in the scene \(buoys, obstacles, etc.\) are using the buoyancy plugin for the sync’ed version - so perhaps not a completely fair comparison.

**Visual Comparison**

To create a visual comparison we ran the same three wave conditions \(described below\) in both implementation \(sync’ed \(the PR\) and not-synch’ed \(current default\)\). The [video](https://vimeo.com/342859838) illustrates the quantitative results. This suggests that the synchronization becomes more noticeable to the user and sensor with higher seastates - larger amplitude, higher period waves.

Case 0: Typical, low seastate conditions.

```
[Msg] Input Parameters:
[Msg] model:     PMS
[Msg] number:     3
[Msg] scale:      1.5
[Msg] angle:      0.4
[Msg] steepness:  0
[Msg] amplitude:  0.1
[Msg] period:     6
[Msg] direction:  1 0
[Msg] tau:  1
[Msg] gain:  0.2
[Msg] Derived Parameters:
[Msg] amplitudes:  0.0153085, 0.0786791, 0.0516463, 
[Msg] wavenumbers: 0.0497335, 0.1119, 0.251776, 
[Msg] omegas:      0.698132, 1.0472, 1.5708, 
[Msg] periods:     [Msg] 9, [Msg] 6, [Msg] 4, [Msg] 
[Msg] phases:      0, 0, 0, 
[Msg] steepnesses: 0, 0, 0, 
[Msg] directions:  [Msg] 0.921061 -0.389418; [Msg] 1 0; [Msg] 0.921061 0.389418; [Msg] 
```

Case 1: Highest amplitude short period conditions - upper left of our wave envelope

```
Msg] Wavefield Visual received message on topic [/gazebo/ocean_world/response]
[Msg] Input Parameters:
[Msg] model:     PMS
[Msg] number:     3
[Msg] scale:      1.5
[Msg] angle:      0.4
[Msg] steepness:  0
[Msg] amplitude:  0
[Msg] period:     2
[Msg] direction:  1 0
[Msg] tau:  1
[Msg] gain:  1
[Msg] Derived Parameters:
[Msg] amplitudes:  0.00850471, 0.0437106, 0.0286924, 
[Msg] wavenumbers: 0.447601, 1.0071, 2.26598, 
[Msg] omegas:      2.0944, 3.14159, 4.71239, 
[Msg] periods:     [Msg] 3, [Msg] 2, [Msg] 1.33333, [Msg] 
[Msg] phases:      0, 0, 0, 
[Msg] steepnesses: 0, 0, 0, 
[Msg] directions:  [Msg] 0.921061 -0.389418; [Msg] 1 0; [Msg] 0.921061 0.389418; [Msg] 
```

Case 2: High amplitude, long period, upper-right of our wave envelope

```
[Msg] Wavefield Visual received message on topic [/gazebo/ocean_world/response]
[Msg] Input Parameters:
[Msg] model:     PMS
[Msg] number:     3
[Msg] scale:      1.5
[Msg] angle:      0.4
[Msg] steepness:  0
[Msg] amplitude:  0.1
[Msg] period:     8
[Msg] direction:  1 0
[Msg] tau:  1
[Msg] gain:  0.375
[Msg] Derived Parameters:
[Msg] amplitudes:  0.0510282, 0.262264, 0.172154, 
[Msg] wavenumbers: 0.0279751, 0.0629439, 0.141624, 
[Msg] omegas:      0.523599, 0.785398, 1.1781, 
[Msg] periods:     [Msg] 12, [Msg] 8, [Msg] 5.33333, [Msg] 
[Msg] phases:      0, 0, 0, 
[Msg] steepnesses: 0, 0, 0, 
[Msg] directions:  [Msg] 0.921061 -0.389418; [Msg] 1 0; [Msg] 0.921061 0.389418; [Msg] 
```
content.html:
TLDR: The testing below suggests that if we could simplify the implementation, synchronizing the visual and physical wavefield would add functionality for higher seastates without too much computational or complexity costs.

Based on team discussion, attempting to quantify the tradeoffs involved in this PR

Pros:

  • Additional visual fidelity associated with synchronizing visual and physical ocean model.
  • Additional sensor simulation fidelity for simulation of cameras and lidar.

Cons:

  • Additional code complexity. Current implementation is quite complex. Considering a refactoring to simplify implementation and remove the capability to change wave parameters during simulation
  • Added computational requirements

Computational Requirements

Below are results taken from top to quantify the relative resource usage of the simulation before and after this PR. Note that the proposed modification to simplify the implementation may reduce the computational load. Both implementations ran at RTF ~ 1.0.

Implementation gzserver %CPU gzserver RES / SHR gzclient %CPU gzclient RES/SHR
Not synch’ed (original) 101 441,704 / 144,832 30 370,260 / 138,180
Sync’ed, full implementation before refactor 117 441,484 / 141,436 31 332,272 / 133,396
Sync’ed, refactored implementation. 118 411,556 / 141,368 25 328,396 / 133,364

So, a slight uptick in resource usage. I suspect that this is due to the fact that more objects in the scene (buoys, obstacles, etc.) are using the buoyancy plugin for the sync’ed version - so perhaps not a completely fair comparison.

Visual Comparison

To create a visual comparison we ran the same three wave conditions (described below) in both implementation (sync’ed (the PR) and not-synch’ed (current default)). The video illustrates the quantitative results. This suggests that the synchronization becomes more noticeable to the user and sensor with higher seastates - larger amplitude, higher period waves.

Based on that initial work I’ve connected the method with our WAM-V dynamics and general purpose buoyancy plugins.  

This also implements an additional method for generating the component waves based on a standard family of oceanographic wave spectra.  

Added documentation: 

* [Wavefield Implementation](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/documentation/wavefield_generation): How the model is implemented to keep the visual and physical models in sync.

pull_request.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

pullrequest.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

content.raw:
One problem with this PR is that it uses Param and Param\_V gazebo messages, which I don’t believe are supported in Gazebo 7.x .  Two options would be to…

* Abandon compatibility with Gazebo 7.X and Kinetic
* Remove the message passing functionality and instead have the WavefieldModelPlugin and WavefieldVisualPlugin pass the wave parameters via the WavefieldModelPlugin API which allows access to a shared pointer.  This is the way that the WavefieldModelPlugin and the buoyancy model plugins pass the wave parameters.  The advantage of removing the gazebo messaging would be that it would simplify the code and communication between plugins consistent.  The disadvantage is that it would eliminate the ability of the user to change the wave parameters during a simulation - they would need to be set at run time.   I don’t think the later is much of a problem since that functionality isn’t something we’ll need for VRX.
content.html:
One problem with this PR is that it uses Param and Param_V gazebo messages, which I don’t believe are supported in Gazebo 7.x . Two options would be to…

  • Abandon compatibility with Gazebo 7.X and Kinetic
  • Remove the message passing functionality and instead have the WavefieldModelPlugin and WavefieldVisualPlugin pass the wave parameters via the WavefieldModelPlugin API which allows access to a shared pointer. This is the way that the WavefieldModelPlugin and the buoyancy model plugins pass the wave parameters. The advantage of removing the gazebo messaging would be that it would simplify the code and communication between plugins consistent. The disadvantage is that it would eliminate the ability of the user to change the wave parameters during a simulation - they would need to be set at run time. I don’t think the later is much of a problem since that functionality isn’t something we’ll need for VRX.

pull_request.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

pullrequest.title: New wave generation model and implementation.

content.raw:
This is the demonstration setup I used.

1. Change the ocean wave parameters in \[wave\_gazebo/world\_models/ocean\_waves/model.sdf\]\([#!/osrf/vrx/src/adee246ddab49c232fd3ddb03d6847cfe14ff75e/wave\_gazebo/world\_models/ocean\_waves/model.sdf](#!/osrf/vrx/src/adee246ddab49c232fd3ddb03d6847cfe14ff75e/wave_gazebo/world_models/ocean_waves/model.sdf)\)  
  Particularly the “period” and “gain” values.  The period is the peak period of the wavefield in seconds. The gain is a simple multiplier applied to the component amplitudes.
2. Run the example world with two WAM-V’s, camera view and a few buoys

```
roslaunch wave_gazebo wave_wamv.launch verbose:=true paused:=true
```

I start with it paused to watch better watch the initial transients.

There are a couple videos linked to the [Wavefield Envelope](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/documentation/wavefield_envelope) page which illustrate what you should see.
content.html:
This is the demonstration setup I used.

  1. Change the ocean wave parameters in [wave_gazebo/world_models/ocean_waves/model.sdf](#!/osrf/vrx/src/adee246ddab49c232fd3ddb03d6847cfe14ff75e/wave_gazebo/world_models/ocean_waves/model.sdf)
    Particularly the “period” and “gain” values. The period is the peak period of the wavefield in seconds. The gain is a simple multiplier applied to the component amplitudes.
  2. Run the example world with two WAM-V’s, camera view and a few buoys
roslaunch wave_gazebo wave_wamv.launch verbose:=true paused:=true

I start with it paused to watch better watch the initial transients.

There are a couple videos linked to the Wavefield Envelope page which illustrate what you should see.
